properties.name: Allen Ginsberg's Blake Vision
properties.description: Posted by Red76In 1948, having returned from a brief stint as a sailor on a merchant marine vessel, Allen Ginsberg took over a sublet from a theological student on East 121st, near Columbia University. Ginsberg had been attending the university, on and off, since 1943, and needed only to finish one course in Victorian Literature to graduate. While attending Columbia he had developed a deep appreciation for the work of William Blake, an appreciation that was discouraged at the time by his professors, who considered Blake too far afield a writer for serious consideration. One afternoon, after masturbating in his apartment, Ginsberg "heard the voice of William Blake" receiting his poem "Ah, Sunflower! So Weary of Time". The voice went on to recite "The Sick Rose", as well. This vision weighed on Ginsberg heavily for the next ten years. In this particular timeframe the subject comes up frequently within his journals. It was a moment in time that stayed with him for the rest of his life, and he referred to it as a major breakthrough for himself, providing him with a vision of the "eternal", an infinite consciousness transcending through time, connecting all thought and action with each individual through history, living and deceased.

properties.name: Beating of Johnson X Hinton
properties.description: Posted by Red76506 Lenox Ave. NYC, NY.After intervening in the arrest of a Harlem resident, and being beaten by the arresting officers, Johnson X Hinton, a Black Muslim, was taken to the 38th Precinct House in Harlem. Soon after, news of the incident spread through the Black Muslim community of Harlem, and Malcolm X, and other members of the Nation of Islam, made their way to the police station. They were at first told that Hinton was not being held at the jail. Soon after, they were told that he was, indeed, there, but that Malcolm could not see him. In this time a crowd of over 2,500 Harlem residents, as well as many Black Muslims, who were arranged in neat formation, had gathered outside the police precinct. In time Malcolm was brought to the jail cell where Hinton was housed. He found Hinton bloody and semiconscious. Malcolm informed the police that the crowd would not disperse till Hinton was brought to Harlem Hospital to receive medical treatment. An ambulance was called, and Hinton was brought to the hospital. As the ambulance drove away, with a slight wave of his hand, Malcolm dispersed the crowd. He, and fellow Black Muslim’s, followed the ambulance down Lenox Ave., in formation, to Harlem Hospital. The crowd that had gathered outside the police station followed as well, growing larger as each blocked passed. Malcolm, other members of the Nation of Islam, and the crowd that had begun gathering while at the station, stayed outside the hospital till they were assured that Hinton was receiving the medical attention that he needed to survive. The police captain at the 38th precinct is said to have been overheard saying, “No man should have this much power over that many people. We cannot control this town if one man can wield that kind of power."

properties.name: Conscription Act/Draft Riots
properties.description: Posted by Red76In March Of 1863 The Conscription Act was passed, granting exemption from military service for anyone able to pay a fee of 00; allowing many wealthy Americans to opt out of fighting in the war. The fee in effect, much as now, created an army of the poor. On Saturday, the 11th of July, a crowd began to gather outside of the draft office. Over 1200 names were called that day. The draft lottery was haulted Sunday, to resume Monday morning, July the 13th. Early in the morning, before the office had even yet to open, crowds began to march from lower Manhattan from the Bowery, and the Five Points, up 8th Ave. converging in a vacant lot, east of Central Park. At 8am the crowds gathered into two formations and began making their way to the mid-town draft office, down 5th and 6th Avenues, converging on the draft office located on the corner of 3rd Ave. and 46th St. The estimation of the crowd amassed outside the office was at 10,000, packing the Avenue for a half-dozen blocks on either side of 46th St. Anti-draft placards passed from hand to hand down the street. Ready to ignite, the crowd went into an uproar at the arrival of Volunteer Engine Company 33, known as the Black Joke – a fraternal organization of Five Points street brawlers – whose leader had been picked in the draft. Their aim was to storm the draft office and break the lottery wheel used to draw the names, in addition to burning all the records kept at the office. In the crowd a pistol was fired in the air, and the Black Joke stormed the draft office. After a brutal fight between the mob and police officers and draft officials, and the officials subsequent retreat, the members of the Black Joke destroyed to lottery wheel and promptly set fire to the building. As other volunteer fire companies arrive the building engulfed in flames. The crowd would not let the companies attend to the fire, and the entire block was set ablaze. The riots continued till the following Saturday, reeking havoc and destruction all over Manhattan, including the burning of the 2nd Avenue Armory. As the week went on, the rioters set their sites on black New York residents. On Clarkson St., just north west of West Houston and 7th Ave. William Jones was lynched from a tree after attempting to defend his wife and children and the burning of their home. This was only one of many bloody assaults on black New Yorkers that week.

properties.name: Day's End
properties.description: Posted by Red76In the summer of 1975 Gordon Matta-Clark set about on a project he called, alternately, Day\'s End, or Day\'s Passing. Situating themselves within Pier 52, an abandoned waterfront warehouse on the Hudson River, Matta-Clark and his crew divided whole sections of the 600ft. long, 65ft. wide building - its floor, roof, and siding - cutting huge swaths of material out of the structure and creating an otherworldly trancendent space within the process of doing so. Various visitors would come to the pier during the cutting/de-construction period that summer. Due to a film crew that hoped to make a movie of the processes applying to the city for a filming permit, the police caught wind of the activity. It is said that during this time, when the cops asked Matta-Clark if he had seen Matta-Clark (not knowing who he was at the time) and Matta-Clark replied he had not, they mentioned, "really, what we actually want to know is - how he did it."

properties.name: Fraunces Tavern
properties.description: Posted by Red7654 Pearl St. NYC, NYFraunces Tavern was originally built as a house for Oliver de Lancey, a member of the prominent Delancey family, but was sold to Samuel Fraunces in 1762, who turned the home into one of the most popular taverns of the day. In pre-revolutionary America the tavern served as a meeting spot for the Sons of Liberty, and later, after the war, on December 4th, 1783, George Washington used the tavern to host a farewell banquet for his officers after defeating the British in the Revolutionary War. During the war the tavern suffered damage from a cannon ball fired by the British at America citizens on the Battery. In August of 1775, Americans took possession of cannons from the Battery at the tip of Manhattan and exchanged fire with a boatload of British soldiers. A British gunboat fired on the Americans, sending a cannon ball through the roof of the tavern. Close to two hundred years after this incident, on January 24, 1975, a bomb exploded in the building, killing four and injuring more than 50. The Puerto Rican nationalist group FALN, which had set off other bombs in New York City, claimed responsibility.

properties.name: Helena Keeffe's Dial-A-Story Phone Booth
properties.description: Posted by Red76  Franklin and 3rd, oakland, californiaFor Helena\'s contribution to the Cultural District she cataloged a number of libraries from around the country that had telephone numbers in which you could call and hear a librarian reading a short story. The phone booth had vinyl lettering informing guests to the phonebooth as to what these telephone numbers were, and the location of the library in question. Helena placed candles within the phone booth and handed out quarters to people walking through the neighborhood.

properties.name: Homesteading Riots
properties.description: Posted by Red76514 E. 13th St. NYC, NYOn the morning of May 30, 1995, New York City Police arrived outside 541 and 545 East 13th Street, on the pretense of evicting a group of people who had, for sometime, occupied and rehabilitated the buildings in question. The police were met by doors welded shut, barricades made of over-turned furniture and trashcans in the street. Roughly sixty protesters, who were not residents, helped form a barricade in front of the buildings. Since the late 1970’s many abandoned buildings on the Lower East Side had been taken over and rehabilitated by squatters. In the early 1990’s, as more and more of NYC was becoming gentrified and “improved”, the city regained their interest in these abandoned sites. In August of 2002, after years of hostility, and slow negotiation, the city sold 11 buildings on the Lower East Side for each to the Urban Homesteading Assistance Board, a non-profit agency who have been fighting for affordable housing in New York City since 1973.

properties.name: Infernal Noise Brigade Round-Up
properties.description: Posted by Red76The Infernal Noise Brigade, a marching band comprised of 15 members, was begun in late 1999 to provide the backing track for the protests slated for the WTO convention in Seattle that October. In the summer of 2004 the ensemble made their way to New York for the Republican National Convention. Izaak Mills, an INB ensemble member, explains: “So I can\'t recall a ton but it was like this, in short: The Rude Mechanical Orchestra and the Infernal Noise Brigade were both leading groups of a couple hundred people from two different spots. The INB was at Union Square. The two marching bands met, I believe, at 16th and Irving at about 7 o’clock on the 31st of August. The cops blocked off either side of the street, and what ensued was a wild street party for about 15 minutes until the cops pushed us all onto either side of the street with orange rent-a-fence type stuff and told us we were under arrest. We sat for ages and then were taken by busload to a pier (I think maybe 76 or something) that was emptied out and had several fenced off areas (girls here, guys here kind of thing). The floor was cement and covered in black gasoline residue. I believe it was about 9 or 10 AM when I was taken to Central Booking and led around on a chain gang of 5 through the catacombs. About 24 hours later I was released with a DAT (desk appearance ticket) for a month later (Oct 1). I made it somehow and was left with an ACD (adjournment contemplating dismissal).”

properties.name: Mother Earth
properties.description: Posted by Red76210 E. 13th St. NYC, NYFrom March1906 – August1917 Emma Goldman and Alexander Berkman ran Mother Earth, a journal dedicated to radical political causes, labor agitation, and opposition to the U.S. government on a variety of issues: often against imperialistic tendencies. Contributors to the journal included, among many others, Maxwell Bodenheim, Man Ray (contributing a cover illustration) Mabel Dodge, Will Durant, Maxim Gorky, Ben Hecht, Eugene O\'Neill, Robert Allerton Parker, Ben Reitman, Margaret Sanger, and Charles Erskine. In 1918, in the heat of the environment of World War One, federal authorities seized lists naming over 8,000 subscribers to Mother Earth, targeting them for investigation. Along with Mother Earth, Goldman joined in a long line of radical American Pamphleteers. In February of 1916 she was arrested and imprisoned for the distribution of material on birth control.

properties.name: Oakland Temporary Cultural District
properties.description: Posted by Red76  2nd and franklin, oakland, californiaArtists are akin to locusts, driving out residents and raising rent prices soon after their arrival. Why not create an arts district based upon ephemerality and mobility instead of physicality and singular preciousness. Have a group of artists create projects for street corners and sidewalks. Set up shop for a few hours in the middle of the night. Recreate your new arts district somewhere else some other time.

properties.name: Peace Eye Book Store/ Fuck You: A Magazine for the Arts
properties.description: Posted by Red76 147 A Ave. NYC, NY.The Peace Eye Bookstore was founded by poet, activist, musician, et al, Ed Sanders, and, along with selling short run mimeographed publications and broadsides, served as a community center, print shop, and an underground stopover for those fleeing the USA towards points elsewhere during the Vietnam War. The store also served as an art gallery; housing the first exhibits for artists such as R. Crumb, Art Spiegelman, and Spain Rodriguez. Rodriguez painted the signage for the shop, as well as the signage for the Yippie/Digger Free Store located around the corner on 10th St. Peace Eye was also the home base for the publication Fuck You: A Magazine for the Arts, and Fuck You Press. Fuck You: A Magazine for the Arts published thirteen issues between 1962 - 1965, and featured the work of Tuli Kupferberg (also of the musical/activist outfit The Fugs, along with Sanders), Carol Bergé, John Wieners, Andy Warhol, Ray Bremser, Charles Olson, Peter Orlovsky, Philip Whalen, Allen Ginsberg, Herbert Huncke, Julian Beck, Frank O\'Hara, Leroi Jones, Diane DiPrima, William Burroughs, Gary Snyder, Robert Kelly, Judith Malina, Carl Solomon, Gregory Corso, Robert Duncan, Robert Creeley, Michael McClure, Ted Berrigan, Joe Brainard, and Gilbert Sorrentino, among many others.

properties.name: Punching Marc Bruton in the Face
properties.description: Posted by Red76Sam Gould writes: “I’ve never been one that was prone towards violent physical aggression. Okay, well hardly ever: on occasion, it’s happened. In the summer 1999 I was out of a job and living in Brooklyn, not very sure of what directions my life was headed, and feeling rather crappy. My friend Marc and I would often go out drinking with one another, and whatever money, we could muster between the two of us. Towards the end of those nights Marc usually ending up talking about what a horrible state his life was. That summer the times those portions of the evening usually arose started arriving sooner and sooner. These were not what most would call “happy times”. One day Marc, and our friend Miriam, spent the afternoon at Coney Island. I rode the Wonder Wheel (one of the few things that invariably made me happy in this period of my life). Later we bought some beers to drink while staring out at New York Bay, sitting on the rocks by the water near Amherst St. After spending much of the remainder of the day and night at a bar drinking and playing pool somewhere in Brighton Beach the three of us took off and started walking to the subway. I’m not sure how it all came about; Marc started pushing me, at first playfully. This pushing kept going on, and soon something came over Marc’s face that made it seem like it wasn’t playful anymore. Out of the blue he took a swing at me and missed. Instinctually I threw a punch and knock him in the hard jaw, sending him flying back in one swift motion against a gated up storefront. Within this entire period I wasn’t at all mad, just reacting to the situation at hand, it seemed. I stood over Marc and offered my hand, trying to help him to his feet. Miriam told me to just leave. I got onto the subway and never saw either of them again. Oddly, this may have been one of the best things that ever happened to me. I felt freer. Soon after this incident I made the decision to leave New York. Having grown up in the area I was sick of it, and within a few months I packed up all my belongings and moved about as far away, within the continental U.S. as possible, to Portland, Oregon: free from the bonds of history.”

properties.name: Sincerly, John Head Tailgating Party
properties.description: Posted by Red76   2nd and franklin, Oakland, CA.Sincerly, John Head has been holding tailgating parties around the Pacific Northwest of late. They join the temporary cultural district and tailgating on Franklin St. btw. 2nd and 3rd.

properties.name: Yippie Money Action
properties.description: Posted by Red7611 Wall St. NYC, NY.An action that helped bring about a name for the group of activists, poets, and artists working with, or near, one another in the late 1960’s; Abbie Hoffman, Jerry Rubin, and Stew Albert, were in the center of the first Yippie action, which took place at the New York Stock Exchange in April of 1967. A quickly planned caper, Hoffman went around the East Village and gathered together funds to bring to the NY Stock Exchange the next day with Rubin and Albert. Like much Yippie history, myth precedes fact. Hoffman say’s that he gathered 00 and converted it to small bills, others say thousands, still others say, it was all Monopoly money. The group went down to Wall Street, and, along with fellow tourists, went on a tour of the Stock Exchange. When word got out that there might be something afoot at the Stock Exchange, someone called the press. As the tour reached its apex, looking out over the Exchange floor, Hoffman, Rubin, and Albert, preceded to throw to money that they had gathered over the balcony and onto the floor, and the stockbrokers, below. When the brokers realized that there was money falling from above the went wild, clawing and grabbing for the cash, running and jumping over one another. As no press are allowed on the Exchange floor, a report of the actual event was left up to their imagination. Various accounts of what actually occurred went to press all over the New York newspapers, and nightly news, and well as the national, and international, wire service. One tourist, from the mid-west, who was on the tour of the Stock Exchange, and was seen to join in with the soon to be Yippies, taking money out of his own wallet and throwing it over the balcony, was quoted in the New York Post as to why he joined in on the action as saying, “Well, I’ve been throwing my money away the entire time I’ve been here on vacation. This looked quicker and more fun.”

properties.name: Yippie/Digger Free Store
properties.description: Posted by Red76264 East Tenth St. NYC, NYAn early, pre-Yippie, action taken on by Abbie Hoffman, the Digger Free Store was exactly that – a store wherein everything was free; clothing, televisions, cookware, whatever came into the shop. The store took its inspiration from a free store opened by The Diggers in San Francisco. The SF Diggers were a group of "community anarchists" who operated in the Bay Area from 1966 – 1968. The SF Diggers were formed during planning sessions for the Artists Liberation Front and took their inspiration from The Diggers that operated during the English Civil Wars. An article on the Free Store appeared in the October 14th, 1967 The New Yorker; “When Clyde, Susan, Diego, and Richie are asked to explain why they are performing these services for the lower East Side community, each repeats the enigmatic Digger motto: “Diggers do.” ”
